evidence: Impulse isn’t limited to rectangular shapes.
different Gaussian curves - whether wide or narrow, flat or sharp - can all serve as impulse-like inputs.
What matters is the area under each curve.
This area represents the total impulse delivered by the force.
we often abstract away the exact shape of a signal and focus instead on its integrated effect - the impulse.

triples.evidence: different Gaussian curves - whether wide or narrow, flat or sharp - can all serve as impulse-like inputs.
What matters is the area under each curve. This area represents the total impulse delivered by the force
triples.o: total impulse delivered by the force

evidence: different Gaussian curves - whether wide or narrow, flat or sharp - can all serve as impulse-like inputs.
As long as that area remains the same, the impact on the system is the same.
we often abstract away the exact shape of a signal and focus instead on its integrated effect - the impulse.

concepts.term: This insight is critical in both physics and engineering: we often abstract away the exact shape of a signal and focus instead on its integrated effect - the impulse

evidence: This area represents the total impulse delivered by the force, regardless of how the function looks.
triples.o: total impulse delivered by the force

evidence: Impulse isn’t limited to rectangular shapes. We can see in this graph that different Gaussian curves - whether wide or narrow, flat or sharp - can all serve as impulse-like inputs.
This insight is critical in both physics and engineering: we often abstract away the exact shape of a signal and focus instead on its integrated effect - the impulse.
